narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned how to read econometrics papers even without a strong quantitative background
I learned about current econometric studies in the field of internal conflict, whether that be through terrorist attacks, civil wars or displaced populations.
Good overview of the causes of conflict; good review of econometric analyses and how to read empirical work
Learned how to analyze academic papers better and how various econometric models are designed.
How to interpret econometric techniques within papers, and analyze outcomes of such papers.
I learned to read econometric papers with a critical lens.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The professor tends to use most of the class to speak his mind about the papers assigned. While that was interesting and he was incredibly passionate and knowledgeable, a bit of structure to the discussions would have been nice such as using the powerpoint slides he would post to canvas, rather than just tallking.

I really enjoyed the format of the course and I feel like I have learned many things in a relatively low stakes environment. However, one thing I would complain is the imbalance in the readings that each person had to do for their presentation. I had to read two very dense papers that took me more than 2 full days to go over and then I really struggled to fit everything in my presentation. However, other people had much shorter papers and many times had only one to do. I hope that the next time this course is taught that the professor will make sure that there is a better balance between the readings so that it is fair to everyone. Also, I would have liked to receive more feedback on my papers and presentation.

Strengths: interesting content; professor is very passionate


Weaknesses: format of class is sometimes not engaging (when almost half of class is student presentations, it is hard to pay attention sometimes at the beginning, especially at 9am!)
Everything was great except maybe for the fact that we had 1 long lecture a week, which can be very exhausting, especially over zoom.

strengths: prof padro is a really great teacher and focuses as much on developing skills (analyzing + critiquing econometric papers) as on teaching content (economics of conflict), which is surprisingly rare at Yale and incredibly helpful -- I'm likely to forget the content I memorized in survey courses, but will continue to use the analytical techniques / modes of thinking that Gerard encouraged us to develop. weakness: zoom was super awkward, though I'd attribute this to senioritis, not to the professor...

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you enjoy reading interesting economics papers with a professor passionate about its topics
Yes definitely! If you enjoy learning about current affairs & the world at war and you are big on econometrics then this is the perfect course for you.
Gerard is a very knowledgeable and supportive professor, it was a pleasure taking this class with him.

Yes! It is a course that applies theoretical skills learned in introductory economics courses to real world problems (conflict). It is also nice that the course stays engaging throughout, and you also get to see how you've improved with each additional paper we read.
